result.execSummary:
The defendant Thomas R Johnson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of THC (2nd+ Offense), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Must register with Probation today (3/18/16) or by the close of business on 3/21/16.
Probation may request an early discharge if they feel necessary.

miscConds.notes: $290.60 fine/cost to be paid to the Clerk of Court's Office.  Bond to be applied.
Must provide DNA sample and pay a $250.00 DNA surcharge.  Bond to be applied.
May not possess or use firearms or body armor.

Not to have ABUSIVE contact with Stephanie Athey.  
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  
If not a US citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
Must undergo COMPAS evaluation and follow through with criminogenic needs as recommended by Probation.

timeConds.notes: Banked/stayed for use by Probation if necessary.

supervisions.notes: Subject to Good Time & Work Release.

Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program & Challenge Incarceration Program.
May not vote or hold public office until civil rights are restored.  Other civil rights may be lost until restored.  If not a U.S. Citizen, may face deportation or loss of other citizenship rights.
May not possess or use firearms and, if considered a violent felony, no body armor.
